title: How long should college application essays be? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on what school you’re applying to (It’s very important to learn everything about requirements). The required length at Harvard: We ask that you limit your statement to two pages, double spaced, using a font size that is comfortable to read (not less than 11 point). The required length at UCAS: You can write up to 4,000 characters of text that show you’d make a great student – so it might take a few redrafts until you’re happy with it. (About 750 words or two pages). So I guess 750 words (or about 2 pages) is a typical length for an application essay but you definitely need to look at requirements. And a great tool that will help you with word count: Online Char Count.

Most schools give applicants some idea of the limits on essays. For example, the Common Application, which is used by many schools in the US, gives these guidelines: The Common Application will be maintaining the word limit of 650 words for the “personal statement” essay for 2015. 650 words is the limit, not the goal. The application will not accept a response shorter than 250 words or greater than 650 words. It is not the length that matters nearly as much as what you have to say and the way you write it. One of the best essays I have ever read was short, but it was so because the writer demonstrated wit and exceptionally good writing skills: Parke Muth, consultant: Voices: Flash Essay Workshop   I generally encourage students to write something that will approach the upper limit of the word count. Essays are one of the few ways to humanize the process now that interviews are rare and numbers are what get looked at first. At highly selective schools the essay gives students a chance to say something that will help them stand out from many other strong students.

For the first time, the Common App will strictly enforce the limit of 250 to 650 words. Additionally, the 150-word activities and extracurriculars paragraph is now gone, so you can focus your time and energy on the bigger essay. Generally speaking, colleges might suggest that essays be about 650 words long. Although there really aren't any official requirements, you can keep a few points in mind that will help guide the length of your essay. These points include: Stick to the point.

Sometimes, the college themselves specify a limit on length, however, if you’ve had any significant writing experience you will understand that an essay should only be as long as is necessary. Attempts to make it longer than that will result in reduction of quality.

Usually you will have that specified in the prompt. If it is not specified then write as much as you believe necessary. Your main essay should be around 500–650 words and you should try to answer all the other prompts no more than 150 words below the upper limit.
Like the old sexist saying. It should be like a skirt. Short enough to be interesting, but long enough to cover everything.

Every college application - Common app, Texas App, etc has essay applicable to all the school. This is typically 100 to 500 words. Then there is college specific essays that varies from 100 to 1000 words.

I think the tool which you use Common Application or college’s own tool will guide you further. They typically mention words limit count for each essay prompt, which we need to follow or the tool will not take additional words. Hence, no uniform guideline is available.

The short answer is yes. On the Common Application, the main essay has a limit of 650 words. For supplemental essays, which differ from school to school, the word limit will be listed next to the question. Sometimes there is a word limit, sometimes a word range, sometimes a suggested length, and sometimes a character limit. Always follows the guidelines.
